results.title: Il Trovatore
results.creator_credit: National Video Corporation, Radiotelevisione Italiana, Giuseppe Patroni Griffi and Brian Large
results.brief_description: This production of Giuseppe Verdi’s “Il Trovatore” with Libretto by Salvatore Cammarano, in four acts, was performed at the magnificent outdoor theatre, the Arena di Verona in 1985. Set in the environs of Zaragoza, the capital of the Kingdom of Aragon, and in the mountains of Biscay, around 1412, the story consists of three intertwining sub-plots - war, love and revenge. Dramatic and stirring “Il Trovatore” features an excellent lead cast in singers Giorgio Zancanaro (Count Di Luna), Rosalind Plowright (Leonora), Fiorenza Cossotto (Azucena) and Franco Bonisolli (Manrico) supported by the Orchestra and Chorus of the Arena di Verona, chorus master Tullio Boni, conductor Reynald Giovaninetti. A Verdi masterpiece. Sung in Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: Il Trittico
results.creator_credit: National Video Corporation, Radiotelevisione Italiana, Sylvano Bussotti and Brian Large
results.brief_description: Giacomo Puccini’s “Il Trittico” was recorded live in 1983 at the Teatro alla Scalla, Milan, and featured the Chorus and Orchestra of La Scala, Milan with chorus master Romano Gandolfi and conductor Gianandrea Gavazzeni. “Il Trittico” consists of three one act operas each contrasting in its mood and style and yet all three combining to make an interesting and entertaining program. “Il Tabarro” - music by Puccini, libretto by Giuseppe Adami. A tragic domestic drama of clandestine love, desire and death set in Paris and featuring singers Piero Cappuccilli (Michele, a bargeman), Sylvia Sass (Michele’s wife, Giorgetta) and Nicola Martinucci (Luigi, a penniless stevedore and Giorgetta’s lover). “Suor Angelica” - music by Puccini, libretto by Giovacchino Forzano. A sad and gentle tale of a noble, but disgraced, princess who sought solace in becoming a nun. Set in a convent in the latter part of the 17th century and featuring singers Rosalind Plowright (Sister Angelica, the disgraced princess), Dunja Vejzovich (the Princess and aunt to Sister Angelica) and Maria Grazia Allegri (the Abbess). “Gianni Schicchi” - music by Puccini, libretto by Giovacchino Forzano. A witty and humorous tale of family, greed and deception set in 13th century Florence and featuring singers Juan Pons (Gianni Schicchi), Cecilia Gasdia (Lauretta, Schicci’s daughter), Yuri Marusin (Rinuccio, Lauretta’s lover) and Eleonora Jankovic (Zita, Rinuccio’s aunt). Sung in Italian with no English subtitles. Contains guidebook with English translations.

results.title: Il re pastore
results.creator_credit: Cami Video ORF ZDF Production, John Cox and Brian Large
results.brief_description: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart’s “Il re Pastore” is presented by the International Mozarteum Foundation Salzburg in association with the Landestheater Salzburg for the 1989 Mozart Week. It tells the story of Alessandro (Alexander the Great) who has freed the city of Sidon from the tyranny of Strato and decides to restore the throne to the legitimate heir. Alessandro discovers that the heir is Aminta, a shepherd. Sung in Italian. Contains Libretto by Pietro Metastasio. Performers include: Angela Maria Blasi, Sylvia McNair, Iris Vermillion, Jerry Hadley, Claes H. Ahnsjo. Academy of St Martin in the Fields (London) conducted by Sir Neville Marriner. Staged by John Cox.

results.title: Il Mefistofele
results.creator_credit: Valiant SRL Productions and Ken Russell
results.brief_description: Il Mefistofele is Boito’s best-known work, an opera composed to his own libretto based on Goethe’s work. It was first performed in 1868. This world acclaimed production by Ken Russell, giving a modern interpretation to this opera, was first presented by the Genoese Opera and has toured widely throughout the world. (not subtitled)

results.title: Il Est Minuit, Docteur Schweitzer
results.brief_description:
This biopic of Albert Schweitzer follows the young graduate of Medical school all the way to Gabon where he sets up a dispensary with the help of nurse Marie Winter. Their effort are interrupted with the onset of World War I as Albert realises he is a German citizen established in a French colony. See also: ‘Le Grand Blanc de Lambarene’(NLA #2108812, VHS).

Credits: Producer, Georges Bernier ; director, Andre Haguet ; writers, Andre Haguet, Henri-Andre Legrand ; photography, Lucien Joulin ; music, Maurice-Paul Guillot.
Cast: Pierre Fresnay, Jeanne Moreau, Raymond Rouleau, Jany Vallieres, Jean Debucourt.

results.title: Ikwe
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Michael Scott, Ches Yetman and Norma Bailey
results.brief_description: A young Ojibwa girl of 1770, Ikwe awakens one night from a disturbing dream about a strange man. The arrival of a young Scottish fur trader transforms her dream into reality. Marrying him, Ikwe leaves her village on the shores of Georgian Bay. Although the union promises prosperity for her tribe, it means hardship and isolation for Ikwe. Values and customs clash until, finally, the events of Ikwe’s dream unfold with tragic clarity. Part one of the series entitled Daughters of the Country.

results.title: Ikiru = to live = living = doomed
results.creator_credit: Tokyo Film, Shojiro Motoki and Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description: ‘Ikiru’ is a departure from Kurosawa’s other work and presents a thoughtful and moving piece on life and death. The film opens with an x-ray detailing the stomach cancer of the main character, Kanji Watanabe. The image sets the premise of the piece but not necessarily the tone, which vacillates between hope and despair. Kanji’s physical and mental health is not only damaged by the cancer within, but as Kurosawa subtly suggests, is also contributed to by the inertia of Kanji’s civil service job and life in post-war Tokyo. The film is primarily concerned with Kanji’s struggle to accept his condition and the downwards spiral that drives him to self destructive behaviour. He eventually meets a girl who convinces him that he should spend his dying months doing good. This prompts him to seek approval for having a children’s playground built. The playground will provide a source of enjoyment to the children of the community as well as be an epitaph to good citizen Kanji. Cast includes Takashi Shimura, Nobuo Kaneko, Kyoko Seki and Miki Odagiri. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Ikiru = To live = Living
results.creator_credit: Toho Kabushiki Kaisha and Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description:
A humble civil servant, learning that he is dying of cancer, discovers the meaning of existence - when one lives, one must live entirely. An elaborate and rigorous formal system of symmetrics and asymmetrics contained within the overall ‘rough-hewn geometry’ has been analysed by Noel Burch. The first two-thirds shows Watanabe’s actions, his own reactions to his approaching death. The last third ironically shows the reactions of others - their rejection of Watanabe and the meaning of his death. This sets up a complex interaction between emotional involvement and distanciation. Also available on 16mm, VH and LD.

Credits: Director, Akira Kurosawa ; writers, Akira Kurosawa, Shinobu Hashimoto, Hideo Oguni ; photography, Asaichi Nakai ; music, Fumio Hayasaka.
Cast: Takashi Shimura, Miki Odagiri, Nobuo Kaneko, Kyoko Seki.
